ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course gave me great practice reading, critically analyzing, and presenting scientific literature, especially in areas outside my field. It also allowed me to practice formulating relevant scientific questions about the work I was reading in order to try to think beyond the conclusions in the paper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish we received more specific feedback after our presentations about what we could improve upon. I also would really appreciate NOT having this course so late in the afternoon. It was at the same time as all of the bioethics talks, and so I never got to go to any of them. Also, as it is one of the only days that the med school gives us the afternoon off, it is much easier to be productive if we have bigger chunks of time (i.e. have the class right after lung instead of later in the afternoon). As for strengths, I enjoyed working with faculty mentors to present their work, though some were certainly not as helpful as others. I think when the research mentors are chosen, they should be given a clear idea of what is expected of them, because many did not seem to know. I also would have liked the attendance policy to be made more clear for this course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to others as it gives good practice thinking about how to most effectively present scientific literature, especially to a group of people who are not necessarily familiar with the field.
